comments.commentBody:
I want to see the genuine game plan of every Congressional member. Add to the mix the specific strategy of every political pundit who puts down the President ( no matter what he does ), and top it off with all the folks who make their living through warfare. That would make for an interesting melange of pathways leading to total chaos and probable global warfare.

The visceral emotions brought about by the beheading of two American journalists is real for sure. But to think this country is going to be able to eradicate jihadist terrorism in one fell swoop is like believing that the moon is made of cheese.
Cliff: I agree with you that we shouldn't start this new war, but for different reasons. We are certainly justified. But we shouldn't because  we can't win.

There is nothing that ISIS has done, including the horrific beheadings of two Americans and the ongoing torture/genocide of Iraqi Christians which justifies the US entering a new war. Our participation in this war will only harden hearts in that region and strengthen the resolve of the jihadist fighters. More lives will be lost, more borrowed money spent, more families destroyed and more military men/women injured and for what purpose? Even if ISIS is harmed or held back, history has shown that they will rise up again and rise up with many-fold times the capability, resolve and anger as the last time.

So far, it's unanimous after 12 comments that no one liked this puzzle. I'll add my disapproval. Elaine hit it on the head. It's not a crossword puzzle. I got the general idea and kept trying to make the app accept the answers. But I may have missed a few simply because what I was looking at didn't make any sense to me, and I lost the will to finish (which absolutely never happens to me).

No AHA moment whatsoever, since I was onto the trick early on, so there was absolutely ZERO fun in working through it.

This might have been good as one of the Sunday variety puzzles that I have no qualms about skipping.

And though the venomous post by adara614 was mean-spirited and uncalled-for, it's no coincidence that it appeared today. This puzzle brought out the worst in that commenter because it was such a horrible experience.

Interesting speech. To me, what he actually said was to some degree unimportant because you can't believe anything he says. He has drawn red lines, issued ultimatums... So what? Basically nobody believes him anymore.

HOWEVER, to me, this is the first time he actually sounded like he cares about this country, believes that we are a force for good, and that we should have a leading a part in world politics.

Now, let's see if he carries through with any of this.

Robert, Out West, Sept 10th post

Mr. Obiter raised the topic of climate change extinctions, and it was to him I replied. You interjected with your usual charm and the claim that our times are "one of the great extinction periods of plant and animal species".

Human-induced extinctions are undeniable, especially due to habitat loss. We all know about dodoes and passenger pigeons.

But it is counterfactual nonsense to claim that the present day rivals, say, the Permian extinction and the Triassic extinctions, when 95% of marine life and 70% of land species were wiped out.

According to Mora,C., et al, PLos Biol., 9, 31001127, there are 8.7MM eukaryotic species on our planet, + or - 1.3 MM

Loehle,which you didn't read, says "Our results do not support statements or projections by others of grossly elevated extinction rates for continental bird and mammal fauna over the last 500 years compared to background rates."

Oxford U's Clive Hambler, lecturer on biology, says "It's very important not to cry wolf about species extinction. And...climate change. It's even more important not to cry wolf when these two important issues are combined."

See also He, F., and Hubbell, S.P., Nature 473, 368-371, doi:10.1038/Nature 09985 "Species- Area Relationships Almost Always Overestimate Extinction Rates from Habitat Loss."

Your desire to criminalize me because I disagree with you is a fascist pathology of thought common to deep green true believers. It is odious and contemptible.
We ARE on the border, protecting South Korea.  What is that but policing the world?

Interesting. Can't say I recommend this comment out of approval. But very interesting.

I will say that I don't see ISIS as a static force. It seems that change and the acceptance of new situations is what they are expert at.

With that said, I say this now; end their murdering ways with all speed!

I watched some ISIS propaganda recruiting videos online. My conclusion is many downtrodden, disenfranchised and unaccepted Sunni Arabs from Saudi Arabia to Britain believe ISIS is a meritocracy where they can "be all they can be". Many young Arabs aren't going to feel this "FREEDOM" in Saudi Arabia, to be sure.

ISIS lines up Sunni Arabs from all over the world in these videos to show off the "melting pot" that is ISIS. In that sense, ISIS is borrowing from "the American dream". I saw the VICE documentary too. I couldn't get over how all the Sunni Arab members of ISIS proclaimed the "freedom" they feel ridding themselves of their restrictive pasts. They're like born again Muslims. The identity they feel belonging to ISIS comes across as palpable and intoxicating.

It's uncanny. That being said, I think like all things, reality will set in. ISIS will have to govern because you can't "play pirate" when you control so much land. I think ISIS, the extreme group we now know, will slowly lose its charm and ultimately evolve into a moderate but still very important mover in the region.

I don't think Obama's approach is particularly appealing. It's stale, expensive, could make things worse and could provoke attacks on our homeland. I would have preferred a containment strategy forcing ISIS to govern, where they're sure to lose support when the honeymoon is over.
Right. We think we are rolling uphill ... but what goes up ... !

I'm thankful that we have a thoughtful and determined President who's made a considered set of decisions on how and when we can most successfully intervene in a very difficult and potentially threatening situation for the US. Quite a contract to our dithering and reactive Congress.
No comparison to Israel and the Palestinians. Let's remember 6M reasons why the Jews were offered a homeland. That's a different and unique situation that needs to be resolved on its own terms.
The commentary on this blog seems very superficial and unrealistic missing the point of the uncertainty in real time of how to assess and best react to potential threats to the US and current and real threats to societies we'd like to support and US important interests around the world.

We can't just tell other peoples how to act nor can we fight every potential enemy that seems to threaten us. Knowing just the right path is nearly impossible in the present but easy to criticize. This president has avoided over-committing us to an all out war and has taken a decisive step to limiting and possibly eliminating a real future threat.
Let's be thankful for a strong yet conservative reaction and see how it goes.
And thanks to John Maynard Keynes for the insight that "When my information changes, I alter my conclusions. What do you do, sir?"
Let's be real here and stop the sniping and thank Obama for a careful response to a very complex problem

I read that ISIS actually has an independent funding base from the areas it controls, including Oil wells, and even a real Tax base. So it appears that it is difficult to starve ISIS of funding without boots on the ground.

We can't train and educate students to find work, or teachers.

We've done a "heck of a job" training Afghans and Iraqi armies over the last ten years.

Syrian rebels next! And then Ukrainians.

Endless opportunities for the military industrial complex.

And we have free money on demand from the Fed to keep doing it.

That's nonsense. Al Qaeda didn't attack us because US soldiers were in Saudi Arabia.... Al Qaeda is even stupider then I could have imagined. It's the Saudi government that requested our presence. After all, they wanted Saddam contained.

Al Qaeda should take that up with the Saudis, that was their call. They used it as justification, but that's not the reason for 9/11

Absolutely!  Everyone from Congress, Wall Street,  universities, and Main Street all need to have a stake in this fight.  Otherwise, the burden is not shared equally nor are the benefits shared equally.
So what do you propose to do?
Absolutely correct.

Remember the days, back before Barack Obama became President, when both Parities in Congress would rally behind the Commander-in-Chief when the need to call-up the Troops was to be made? Now, however, Congress seems hesitant to add a vote in favor of the President's decision--apparently for political reasons.

Also, the insanity of it all is even more ridiculous in that the Republicans continue to suggest that the President has been failing to Advise Congress, and by-passing it in its vital Constitutional role of Declaring War and, for that matter, House Speaker John Boehner (R-OH) held a successful House vote to sue President Obama for over-stepping his authority. Really?

Congress doesn't want to go on record to vote Pro or Con confronting the Islamic State, not this close to the Mid-Term Elections. That way, they believe that they can blame Obama--if if today's actions are successful--for not doing it sooner, and also blame him if it blows-up--claiming that he should never have done it.

At least, we have a President--like him or not--who accepts the responsibility when something actually has to be done. Let's deport Congress!

Yep, we all know how this perverse little game is played now; soon we will have to send more troops to protect the troops in place.  Welcome to the world of Mad Max where we won't be happy until the whole planet is in smoking ruins.
What worries me is that our "non-combat" 475 troops will end up like being the "advisers" to Diem during the Kennedy Administration, before the Vietnam War fully erupted.

Pretty easy guess that we would all wake up on 9/11 tomorrow, at war, again... and yes, a stupid one, again... started by another president suckered into it by our own military-industrial complex, with just a little nudge from ISIS social media tactics—a strategy far more baked out than anything coming from this inept US administration. How weak we look to the rest of the world. How weak we are indeed. Strong US resolve would look like the opposite of what's playing out now.

Yes, it's absolutely moronic. Your politicians don't really care what the plan is, as long as they have a plan to sell you on. Call the marketing people, whip up a few speeches, coin a term or two, use the favorite vocabulary like bloviate, conflate, road map, boots on the ground and new paradigm, etc. Then start signing contracts for ordnance. Oh, don't forget to order up 20 million of those little flag lapel pins from China.

“Because Americans are worried and they’re anxious. They want, and deserve, the truth. Most of all, though, they want a plan.”
Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky.

Is this hilarious or wot?

The CheneyBush "war machine" had no intention of really establishing a stable Iraq, but rather securing control of its oil resources and profits for Halliburton and its subsidiary Kellogg and Root through "no-bid" government contracts. The "Project for the New American Century" goal of establishing a Western-style democracy in the Arab Middle East was just window-dressing, much as a unified Europe was Germany's window-dressing for occupation in the early 1940s.
The crucial mistake was the hubristic disbanding of the ONE institution in Iraq that existed since independence in the wake of World War I--the Iraqi Army. The head of the "Interim Authority" (think Gouvernement-General in Poland, 1939-44) Paul Bremer disbanded it in total ignorance of modern Iraqi history. This set the stage for the birth of Al Quaeda in Iraq (now ISIS/ISIL), which did NOT exist in Saddam's Iraq.

It is not just that no man should have this much authority. No man can.

Who can bear the weight of such monumental decisions under constant the scrutiny those who despise you for no reason, or because of the color of your skin. What human being can make such no-win decisions- with no good outcomes- alone?

Congress should have supported Obama in Syria. Or put forth their own resolutions.

Such decisions cannot and should not be made by any one person. It is a weight no one can bare.

My heart goes out to Obama. Who would want his job?

Who would want his job? From my count so far at least a dozen people are lining up for 2016. If he didn't want or didn't think he could handle the responsibility he should have been mature enough, and patriotic enough, not to run for the office.  He lied completely about being a mean of peace, and I supported him in both elections for that reason alone, but his head grew too large, and not from acquiring knowledge.

Perennial war is exactly what Madison warned us about. The framers were almost totally united on the necessity to not place war authority in the hands of the Executive but only in Congress. They were specific about the reason for this as Madison an Hamilton both agreed that A) One man should never have that kind of power, and B) If it is in the Executive's power we will see never ending war, because Presidents and kings get stronger during wartime.
And what have we done? Beginning with the Korean War and ever since, allowed the President to disobey the Constitution and make war, and it's exactly what the framers foresaw would happen.
Joseph in Missoula
Ugly question: Are we willing to commit to the level of violence required to defeat people spreading this ideology of hate. If we are not, our daughters, too, will be slaves.
Sorry. Right. He did say he was always against the war. And in 2007 he voted against funding it. We're were still doopped.

You also use that phrase, "How ironic..." and my replies today focus on that concept. So here a new variant. And now they are becoming our blood brothers on the edge of Iraqi Kurdistan.

And, against my better judgment I add this irony to the more serious:

Agreed, except for the last paragraph. The USA is hardly alone in its love of war. It's just that it has more ability to carry them out.

Perhaps because the US is not really a nation anymore.  It seems to have become what is being called a neo-liberal entity whose chief concerns are not necessarily those of the people who find themselves living here.

The headline just now on the Times front page reads :
'Obama Promises Long Effort to Rout Militants'

How ironic in a country which on a 'good year' created 'only' an additional deficit of half a trillion dollars. Last year there was even talk of privatizing the post office which had a deficit of $2 billion, with some in our Congress bitterly complaining that it just was too expensive for government to maintain.

New projections with the mission in Syria being proposed by Obama are estimated at $1 billion Per Month. Yet food stamp allotments have been cut back for poor families, some of whom were barely making it before on meager rations. Many people very ill die each year due to lack of proper medical care, which hopefully the ACA will address, but it won't help everyone. In Los Angeles, the Times reported recently that many of that city's roads are in severe disrepair. College students may be bound for life to student debt, debt which our bankruptcy courts won't forgive.

But give us a war, any war, and our politicians and their friends salivate in waiting. How many of them have stock in defense contractors, or look to a future life working in that industry or the oil industry?

Why is it that the United States is the only nation in the world which seems to relish war, constant war, war to the point of it being never ending? And who pays for it, our future generations.

The propaganda about the President's no strategy comment is as valuable to the right wing as the Healthcare.gov cataclysm was months before the real test. Nothing like gruesome videos to focus the mind.

This has been an interesting few weeks on a course of indecision for many Americans. Not by President but his detractors, right and some left. A year ago, he wanted to dodge bullets by degrading our enemies in Syria. Now that they are in Iraq, the fake tears of the chicken hawks have dried after diminishing our position in the world again. This situation is complicated.

Not the place for political games. Even if it were as simple as ABCs, we need strong leadership and an aggressive stance to protect life whenever it is possible. Some may argue that killing is wrong and one should agree as long as they keep in mind the lessons of history and careful analysis. C is the best option. We should move about two thirds of the military budget into science and technology research were it will do more good.
